tossups.question: A helix shape formed from a prokaryotic analogue of this protein is thought to serve as an organizer for the PBP2 - peptidoglycan complex. This protein interacts with the charged C-terminal domain of ERM proteins in the cell cortex -- which is primarily made up of this protein. This protein -- whose prokaryotic analogue is MreB -- has its ATP exchanged for ADP by (*) Profilin to promote this protein’s polymerization. This protein binds to CapZ to prevent treadmilling and polymerizes from its globular “G-form” into a filamentous “F-form.” For 10 points, name this protein that forms microfilaments and facilitates muscle contraction with myosin.
tossups.answer: actin < Michael Etzkorn | Biology >
tossups.answer_formatted: actin < Michael Etzkorn | Biology >

tossups.question: This territory fought its southern neighbor at the Battle of Phillips Corners, part of a conflict ended by the Frostbitten Convention. This state was the site of a failed canal on the Clinton River which had been championed by “Boy Governor” Stevens Mason. In the Election of 1848, a former territorial governor from this state won the (*) Democratic nomination but lost the presidency to Zachary Taylor. Lewis Cass was a politician from this state which feuded with Ohio in the Toledo War. The Upper Peninsula is controlled by, for 10 points, what state which, after the War of 1812, moved its capital to Lansing from Detroit.
tossups.answer: Michigan [or Michigan Territory] < Sarod Nori | US History >

tossups.question: In an analysis of these texts, Joseph Schacht, building upon the work of Ignác Goldziher, argued that they were less important than local customs on the influence of indigenous laws. Umar disapproved of and may have banned the recording of these texts. Strong versions of these documents are verified with a chain of transmission, known as (*) isnad. Religious scholars differ over whether four or six books of these works are authoritative. Authoritative collections of these texts was compiled by Muslim ibn al-Hajjaj and al-Bukhari, and they form much of Sunnah. Aisha was the primary source of, for 10 points, what religious texts which record the actions and sayings of the prophet Muhammad?

This author of (*) Vineland wrote a novel whose convoluted plot begins with Roger Mexico discovering the protagonist’s sexual activities can predict rocket strikes. A speaker hears “mind-forged manacles” and “wanders thro’ each charter’d street” in a William Blake poem set in this city. That film from this country is set in the same time period as a 2012 film (*) by Ben Affleck that features the CIA agent Tony Mendez who claims to be filming the science fiction movie Argo, during this country’s Islamic Revolution. tossups.question: The partial derivative of a function, whose output is this quantity, is determined in neoclassical models by the Inada conditions. When the elasticity of substitution is set equal to one, this quantity is equal to A times L to the beta times K to the alpha in a function developed by Charles Cobb and Paul Douglas. It’s not allocation related, but an efficiency named for this quantity is analogous to (*) Pareto optimality. The given resources and technology determine a possibility frontier named for this quantity. Land, labor, capital, and entrepreneurship are defined as the factors of this quantity. GDP is an aggregate measure of, for 10 points, what quantity equal to the number of goods created by a country?

tossups.question: This food stuff is covered in a spicy tomato sauce in the dish Bourdeto. Thin blades are used to cut one type of this food stuff in the technique usuzukuri to avoid piercing the liver. This food stuff is seasoned with aji (ah - hee) and cured in citrus juices in Peruvian ceviche dishes. Malaysian street shops are known for curries that use the (*) head of this meat, which sticks out of the crust of the Cornish dish, Stargazy pie. Surströmming is a Swedish dish where this meat is fermented in brine. One variant of this meat must be specially cut to avoid the animal’s tetrodotoxin and is known as Fugu. For 10 points, name this seafood which is paired with “chips” in Britain.
tossups.answer: fish [accept pilchards; accept sardines; accept pufferfish; accept fugu before mentioned; prompt on sushi; prompt on sashimi; prompt on seafood; do NOT accept or prompt on other seafoods like “crab” or “lobster” (which none of these dishes apply to)] < Michael Etzkorn | Other Academic >

tossups.question: One movement from this work begins (read slowly) E, F-sharp, G-sharp, B, B in a quarter, quarter, dotted-eighth, sixteenth, quarter rhythm. This work begins with an E minor Sinfonia, and a later instrumental section of this work depicting shepherds is titled (*) Pifa. The song Ev’ry Valley Shall Be Exalted features in the first section of this work, while the third part of this work contains the soprano air I Know that My Redeemer Liveth. Following the alleged tradition of King George II, people commonly stand during a section that includes the lyric, “For the Lord God Omnipotent reigneth.” For 10 points, name this George Frideric Handel oratorio that contains the Hallelujah Chorus.

This author created Mr. Washington, who tries to bribe God with a (*) gemstone. Helen fights her husband Charlie Wales for custody of their daughter Honoria in this author’s story “Babylon Revisited.” In a novel by this author, “Owl Eyes” is among the few attendants to a funeral for a West-Egg resident shot in a swimming pool by George Wilson. tossups.question: Einstein names a specific value for this quantity that characterizes the rigidity of a crystal lattice. At constant volume and particle number, the reciprocal of this quantity is defined as the partial derivative of entropy with respect to internal energy. The efficiency of a (*) Carnot cycle only depends on this quantity for the two reservoirs. The radiation of a blackbody is proportional to this quantity to the fourth power according to the Stefan-Boltzmann law. Entropy goes to zero when this quantity equals zero for a perfect crystal, according to the third law of thermodynamics. For 10 points, name this quantity whose SI unit is the kelvin.
tossups.answer: temperature < Michael Etzkorn | Physics >
tossups.answer_formatted: temperature < Michael Etzkorn | Physics >

This goddess is served by a woman who carries a wooden box with ugher shoes named (*) Fulla and a figure that rides the horse Hofvarpnir, named Gna. tossups.question: A chiral compound containing two atoms of this element binds to ruthenium in a catalyst utilized for Noyori’s asymmetric hydrogenation of ketones. Rhodium is bound by chlorine and three atoms of this element in Wilkinson’s catalyst. This element is bound to fluorine in sarin. A common reagent for converting alcohols to (*) bromine contains three bromides bound to this element. This element was discovered by Hennig Brendt by distilling urine. This element glows in the dark in its “white” allotrope form which is a deadly toxin -- unlike this element’s red form. The hand of this sculpture was found in a storage drawer at the Kunsthistorisches (koonst his-TOR-ishes) Museum, which holds a second version of this sculpture. This sculpture was likely created to commemorate the Battle of Cos, which explains why its base originally depicted the prow of a ship. (*) Filippo Marinetti said “a roaring motor car” was more beautiful this sculpture. This work was found by the archeologist Charles Champoiseau (shawm-PWAH-zo). tossups.question: The taxonomy of a state fossil from this geologic period, Tullimonstrum gregarium, has become controversial because of its unusual anatomy. Scientists initially misidentified a eurypterid from this period as a massive spider. This period saw the appearance of Hylonomus, the first amniotic reptile. A namesake (*) rainforest collapse in this period may have been caused by the formation of the Skagerrak Plume. Due to high atmospheric oxygen content, massive arthropods dominated this period which is divided into the Mississippian and Pennsylvanian epochs. Magnificence and gentleness are traits that individuals should seek to attain according to this work’s Doctrine of the Mean. bonuses.leadin: The Kerr metric features examples of these structures along which time does not flow. For 10 points each:
answers: geodesics [prompt on world lines]
world lines
space and time [accept spacetime; accept answers in either order] < Iain Carpenter | Physics >
parts: Name these constructs which generalizes the idea of a “straight line” to higher dimensions. Particles fall along these structures.
Geodesics are specific examples of these entities. Light cones bound these structures which map an object’s history on a Minkowski diagram.

On Minkowski diagrams, world lines are plotted with respect to these two quantities. These two concepts are fused together to create a four-dimensional manifold, whose curvature is related to gravity, in general relativity.
answers_formatted: space and time < Iain Carpenter | Physics > [accept spacetime; accept answers in either order]
acceptable: space and time < Iain Carpenter | Physics >
space and time < Iain Carpenter | Physics >

bonuses.leadin: While this figure was exiled at King Etzel’s court, he was challenged to an inconclusive battle by Wenezlan, the king of Poland. For 10 points each:
answers: Dietrich von Bern [prompt on von Bern]
dragons
dwarfs [or dwarves; accept a small child (on a technicality of some translations)] < Ethan Ashbrook | Mythology, Legends, and Stories >
parts: Name this legendary hero who fought his evil uncle Ermenrich, the ruler of Verona, at several encounters, such as the Battle of Ravenna.
Dietrich’s adventures through Germany involved fighting these creatures, one of which kills his partner Ortnit. Fafnir is an example of these fire-breathing serpents in Norse mythology.

Dietrich has numerous run-ins with these creatures, such as Laurin and Goldemar. In Ortnit’s title poem, Ortnit meets one of these creatures named Alberich, who can only be seen while wearing a magical ring.

American westward expansion inspired this American-German member of the Hudson River School to paint works like Among the Sierra Nevada and The Rocky Mountains, Lander’s Peak.

bonuses.leadin: This composer’s Pavane for a Dead Princess was premiered by his friend Ricardo Viñes. For 10 points each:
answers: Maurice Ravel
Gabriel Fauré
Dolly Suite < Dylan Bowman | Music >
parts: Name this composer who depicted a Spanish dance in his piece Bolero.
Ravel’s most famous teacher was this composer who, like his student, wrote a famous Pavane. His requiem ends with the movement In Paradisum.
This suite for piano four-hands by Fauré was written for Helene Bardac, with whom he had an affair. It opens with a famous Berceuse (bur-sooze) and its fourth movement is known as the Kitty waltz.

bonuses.leadin: This process can result in the formation of Eigen and Zundel cations. For 10 points each:
answers: Grotthuss mechanism [prompt on proton jumping]
superacids [do NOT accept or prompt on “acid”s]
water [or H2O] < Dylan Bowman / Michael Etzkorn | Chemistry >
parts: Name this mechanism proposed by a German scientist, where a proton diffuses through a network of hydrogen bonds.

This class of molecules experiences the Grotthuss mechanism due to the “naked” protons that they contain. This specific class of molecules are defined as having a Hammett function of less than 12 and usually contain a very stable fluorine atom willing to give up a hydrogen.

The Grotthuss mechanism most notably occurs in this molecule. This bent molecule is often called a “universal solvent” for its ability to break down substances by stabilizing them with hydrogen bonds.
acceptable: water < Dylan Bowman / Michael Etzkorn | Chemistry >
water < Dylan Bowman / Michael Etzkorn | Chemistry >

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about Roman relations with Germania. For 10 points each:
answers: Publius Quinctilius Varus
Arminius [or Hermann; or Armin; or Irmin]

parts: Augustus told this man to “give me back my legions” after the battle of Teutoburg Forest. This man, the first Roman governor of Germania, committed suicide after losing three legions in the battle.
This Germanic chieftain was victorious at the battle of Teutoburg Forest. His namesake “denkmal” is a statue of him located in Detmold in eastern North Rhine-Westphalia.
The battle of Teutoburg Forest hindered the Roman expansion into Germania and contributed to the rise of this Germanic tribe which split from the Visigoths.
answers_formatted: Ostrogoths < Sarod Nori | Classics, Britain, or Commonwealth > [do NOT accept or prompt on "Goths"]
acceptable: Ostrogoths < Sarod Nori | Classics, Britain, or Commonwealth >

Gustáv Husák < Sarod Nori | Continental Europe History >
parts: Name this former country. Alexander Dubcek promulgated the ideology of “socialism with a human face” during the Prague Spring in this country.
The dissolution of Czechoslovakia is sometimes known by this name in reference to a similarly named “Revolution” which saw the downfall of the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia.
This last Communist president of Czechoslovakia was overthrown in the Velvet Revolution. His controversial policy of “normalization” saw a return to pre-Prague Spring conditions.
